Why do I like CQRS so much???
One of the best and rarely emphasised benefits of #CQRS is enabling that "green field" development feeling thoughout a long-term, large project. This is gold!
Each read model can be treated like your little happy path 1st week with Ruby on Rails "rails new". Harness happy devs!

What ordinarily happens on software projects is that the solution succumbs to "cyclomatic complexity" - or in plain English, lots of things get connected together in what looks like a knot in fishing line or a cobweb.

This complexity is usually born out of really good intentions like "don't repeat yourself", "data normalisation", "3rd normal form", "code reuse". The reality is that this ties things together to the point that a lot of coordination between teams and individuals must be accommodated. Work ends up as lots of meetings, not a lot of actual construction of the solution.

If we focus on keeping things separate and use other means to gain the integrity of the solution as a whole, we can avoid that. This is done well with Event Storming. That practice produces the blueprints much like a plan you have when you are building a large house. You don't schedule daily or weekly meetings with the plumbers and electricians, right?
Next, how to do this with legacy code!

Since VANTUG's inception, the interest from the membership has been centered around learning both about the newer technologies as well as to seek out other members that may have knowledge to share. Many members have developer, IT Pro, Database or Office certifications providing access to a wide range of personal networking opportunities. The group focuses primarily on those topics and technologies that are of interest to IT pros.

We are pivoting to VR WTF from VRTech World.  This move should help us build traction.  We are in stealth development until market conditions and our budgets improve.  Meanwhile we look forward to investigating and sharing knowledge on Virtual Reality, Augmented Reality as well as Mixed Reality. The media landscape is changing and we intend to move forward with the changes embracing them fully. Today we have developer and innovator editions of Virtual Reality Headsets that are functional and oh so sweet.  Samsung VR Gear is leading Mobile while Oculus, PlayStation, and HTC are all releasing next generation hardware.  The future is exciting.Got VR?

Created as the Vancouver NT Users Group in 1996, the group changed it's name to the Vancouver Technology User Group in 2002.  -  20 Years Old This Year!   VanTUG is 20 in 2016!.    Join us for a full Spring celebration as we host a variety of monthly General Meetings at BCTIA.org and a full day seminar dubbed "SpringTech"Since VANTUG's inception, the interest from the membership has been centered around learning both about the newer technologies as well as to seek out other members that may have knowledge to share. Many members have developer, IT Pro, database or Office certifications providing access to a wide range of personal networking opportunities.The group focuses primarily on those topics and technologies that are of interest to IT pros. The hunger for information and knowledge sharing will always be there and VANTUG has played, and will continue to play, an important role in facilitating this.  We thank our Sponsors and Patrons who continue to support our events.  Vantug is a volunteer organization and we thank all the volunteers that make our events successful.  It is amazing how many people pitch in along the way to keep us moving forward.

When you call Tech Support, you are normally frustrated, flustered and maybe even angry. Tech Support is one of the hardest IT jobs because the customers you are dealing with are customers with problems. It takes a special kind of person to handle those calls, to even go above and beyond with those types of calls, this is James. I worked around James and on a daily basis I heard him handle calls with precision, with professionalism and with the IT knowledge to get the job done. He was always the outgoing person in the office to talk to everyone, be friendly and even offer advice to help solve other problems. James has a broad knowledge of the IT world and he surprises me with how determined he is to learn more and more each day. I would recommend James for any company who is looking for a trustworthy, outgoing, friendly and technically smart IT team member.
Justin Smith

Sean Carson
Technical Lead  DevOPS - FIFA Japan at Electronic Arts (EA)
February 26, 2013, James worked with Sean in different groups

I worked with Sean for almost two years in the Technical Operations Department.    Sean was the lead Network Administrator  while I worked in the customer facing side as part of the Technical Support Team at Faronics Corporation.  Sean onboarded me when I joined Faronics and later I had the opportunity to work with Sean in a couple of in-house and cloud migration projects. I found Sean's peer-to-peer mentoring and support to be exceptional.   He can quickly evaluate team members skills and knowledge levels and communicate quickly and efficiently to get the job done.  Sean's diligence and interpersonal skills made it easy for him to work will anyone in the organization from the C-suite to the front line. He would not hesitate to state the obvious - good bad or ugly to ensure all stake holders were aware of what needed to be done.  Sean is a knowledgeable administrator capable of managing any network deployment scenario.  His cross platform experience and knowledge with Linux / LAMP / Windows servers is phenomenal. He is the go to guy.  Sean was responsible for managing all internal servers, PBX - phone systems,  Security Monitoring and Authorization, Migration to Hosted Services,  Management of Exchange Servers & eventual Migration to Cloud Services.  Sean also mentored the Desktop Support staff who's primary role was managing internal user issues. Additionally Sean negotiated and managed Vendor Contracts & SLA's as well as Internal Stakeholder SLA's.Sean is at home in any technology and I would not hesitate to recommend him for any role he he feels capable of challenging.

summary: Welcome to MR.Tips I'm a VR Enthusiast and love VR, AR, Mixed Reality and Merged Reality.I am a connector of sorts.  I build connections and help people pursue their dreams.    My day job is to sell domains, domain management services, emails services, and SSL Certificates.  I consult to arrange hosting, web development, and event services.   I am a father, adventurer, photographer, videographer, computer and network technician, apprentice web developer and entrepreneur.   I am here to bring value to our connections and build community.  Currently, I am the President of the Vancouver Technology User Group and on the board of other groups.  I volunteer over 300 hrs a year on community organizations hosting 10 + events a year with small teams of volunteers.  Volunteering with the Vancouver Technical User Group (vantug.com) allows me to give back to the tech community. Fostering professional development and honing my skill set helps keep my ear to the ground.Management and supervisory skills have been built over the years as an Independent Business Owner, Supervisor, Manager and Board Member.  Additionally, I completed the International Business Management certificate at Greystone College in Vancouver BC. I have been in the support industry for many years & have been exposed to a variety of situations that make an ideal skill set for Business Technology Integration. My Career has spanned self-employment, Retail Management, Manufacturing, Software Development and National ISP’s as a Hardware and Network support technician. This has allowed me to expand my skills as a Network Administrator and in New Media Development. These skills are converging as I learn to develop for VR/AR & Mixed Reality experiences. I enjoy challenges and look forward to exploring technology every day!Let's connect soon. virtually or in person and discuss what we can do to build value and build community.Virtually Yours, James
